Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the speaker's vote against the Iran deal by repeatedly stating that they were one of the very few who voted against it, implying that it was a rare and significant stance.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific evidence or data to back up the statement that the speaker was one of the few who voted against the Iran deal.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that voting against the Iran deal is a noteworthy and exceptional position to take, without providing any context or justification for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the claim, as it is clarified that the vote referred to in the claim was not an up-or-down vote on the Iran deal itself, but rather a vote on a bill that gave Congress the power to review and potentially reject the deal. This alternative explanation undermines the claim that the speaker was one of the few who voted against the actual Iran deal.
